column2: LMMS - Effecting some Sounds
What you'll do
You've learned how to make a song, how about making your own sounds and sound effects?

Hello again, {{user_name}}! Just can't get enough of LMMS? I've got just the thing. Let's create some sound effects that you could use in a video, or even a retro game! Let's get started - I'll launch LMMS.

OK, here we go! You can close the FX Mixer and Controller Rack windows, we won't need them. Open the Instrument Plugins tab, from the left-hand side of the main window. It has an icon with a wavy line on it, and it's the 3rd one down if you look underneath the File menu.

You should now see a list with some instructions at the top. Select Nescaline from that list, and like the instructions say, drag it into your Song Editor. It should show up at the bottom of the Song Editor, right below the Automation Track.
Now that we have an "instrument," let's change how it sounds. Double-click on Nescaline and a little window should pop up with a lot of red buttons and dials - this is how you'll create your sounds.
First, let's make the sound of a helicopter flying.

Look at the left side of Nescaline - Do you see the little red lights to the left of the CH1, CH2, CH3 and CH4 labels? Click those lights so that only CH4 is red, and others are black. This means we'll only be using Channel 4 for this sound.

Now, in the Channel 4 row, look for the dial with the FREQ label below it. Grab this dial with your mouse and drag up or down to set it to 4 or 5. As you drag, a little label that says "Noise Frequency" and the na number will show up to let you see where the dial is.
Look to the right of FREQ for the dials labeled LEN and SWP. Click on them and drag to make sure they're set to 0.

Just above the LEN and SWP dials, there are 3 buttons like the CH4 button, labeled ENV, ∞ and Q. Turn the first 2 on, and the last one off. The first 2 lights should be red, the last one should be black.
OK, now we're ready. Press any key on your keyboard (Y or D are good choices) to hear the sound!
Now that's a whirlybird incoming!
Let's do another - Drag another Nescaline into the Song Editor, below the first one, and double-click it to open it up.
Let's make a downward "beeeoooooowww" sound now, like something falling.
Turn CH1 on, and CH2, CH3, and CH4 off. Use the buttons just to the left of the labels.
We wnat the VOL dial set to 15 (maximum), the CRS dial set to 0 (that's the middle) and the LEN dial set to 0 (that's the minimum value for it).
To the right of those dials, you should see the WIDTH label, with 4 blocks underneath it. Click the 3rd block, and it should turn red.

Almost there! Now, look to the right of WIDTH and you should see SWEEP. Click the button just to the left of SWEEP to turn it on, then set the AMT dial to -3 (just left of middle) and the RATE dial to 3 (almost exactly at the middle).
Now we're ready to test it out - poke a few keys on your keyboard and hear the "drop"!
Now, what's a falling noise without a nice CRASH at the end?
Brrip! Mia&&w!
I should have know you'd show up as soon as we mentioned something breaking! Well, we can't disappoint him. Drag a 3rd copy of Nescaline into the Song Editor, then double-click it to open it up.
Like the Helicopter sound, this one will only use Channel 4, so let's turn off Channel 1-3
Set the VOL dial to the maximum (15), and the FREQ to 6.
Moving right, let's set the LEN dial to 2 and the SWP dial to 1.
Above those dials, turn ENV, ∞ and Q OFF - The lights should be black.
Finally, to the right of the SWP dial, there's another button labeled NOTE. Turn it ON, so it lights up.
Now test it out on your keyboard. Crash!
Excellent work! Now that you have 3 sound effects to play with, we can pick one and export it into an actual sound file.
For this example, I'm picking the Helicopter sound, but you could use either of the other two if you want.

In order to play these sounds, we'll need to lay down some notes. Look in the Song Editor, in the first Nescaline row, and double-click the first black box to the right of the Pan dial. This should open the Piano Roll window.
In the Piano Roll window, click on the keys until you find one that sounds good (I used C5). Then, click in the black, grid-marked area to the right of that key to create a note.
Once you have a note, click and drag on the left and right ends to change the length. Press Space to listen and test it out!
When you're happy with it, go the File menu and click Export.
Underneath Look In:, click your username, {{user_name}}. Name the file whatever you like, then click Save
The export window will pop up - Make sure that the box next to Export as loop (remove end silence) is checked!
LMMS will export your sound to the hard drive - go to your home directory and look for it. Once you find it, double-click on it to play it in the Music app.
Congratulations! Now you can take this sound and do whatever you want with it - Use it in a game, as a sound effect on a video, as your new phone ringtone, anything you like. It's all yours!
